channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: India is on the hunt for 24 ‘untraceable’ historical treasures
item.dc:creator: By Vidhi Doshi
item.description: Officials are looking for ancient temples, tombs and other historical artifacts lost to natural disasters or development.

item.title: Beijing wins battle for blue skies — but the poor are paying a price
item.dc:creator: By Simon Denyer
item.description: Tens of thousands of polluting factories were forced to clean up their operations or were simply closed, while millions of households were hurriedly shifted off coal-fired heating and onto natural gas.

item.title: These Trump supporters built a gallows and tried to arrest London’s mayor. People laughed at them.
item.dc:creator: By Avi Selk
item.description: "We were distracted by the actions of what some would call very stable geniuses,” Sadiq Khan said afterward.

item.title: These Trump supporters built a gallows and tried to arrest London’s mayor. People laughed at them.
item.dc:creator: Avi Selk
item.description: "We were distracted by the actions of what some would call very stable geniuses,” Sadiq Khan said afterward.

item.title: Iran vows ‘serious response’ to new sanctions and rebuffs Trump’s demands on nuclear deal
item.dc:creator: Carol Morello
item.description: Russia, China and European parties to deal express worry and disapproval of U.S. stance.

item.title: India is on the hunt for 24 ‘untraceable’ historical treasures
item.dc:creator: Vidhi Doshi
item.description: Officials are looking for ancient temples, tombs and other historical artifacts lost to natural disasters or development.

item.title: A leaked draft of the Pentagon's nuclear review shows a desire for new kinds of weapons
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: Smaller nuclear warheads are necessary due to the "deterioration of the strategic environment," the document said.

item.title: Ghanaian president to Trump: We are not a 'shithole country'
item.dc:creator: Adam Taylor
item.description: Nana Akufo-Addo is the latest world leader to respond to Trump's immigration comments.

item.title: These Trump supporters built a gallows and tried to arrest London’s mayor. People laughed at them.
item.dc:creator: Avi Selk
item.description: "We were distracted by the actions of what some would call very stable geniuses,” Sadiq Khan said afterward.

item.title: Ghanaian president to Trump: We are not a 'shithole country'
item.dc:creator: Adam Taylor
item.description: Nana Akufo-Addo is the latest world leader to respond to Trump's immigration comments.

item.title: Can social media become less hateful by law? Germany is trying it - and failing, critics say.
item.dc:creator: Rick Noack
item.description: "Social networks are no charity organizations that guarantee freedom of speech in their terms of service,” a government representative said.

item.title: What does North Korea want from the Olympics? An expert in the politics of sports explains.
item.dc:creator: Adam Taylor
item.description: "It has become blindingly apparent that national pride and national strength are in part reflected in sporting success ... North Korea has embraced that."

item.title: Beijing wins battle for blue skies — but the poor are paying a price
item.dc:creator: Simon Denyer
item.description: The Chinese capital’s success upends the assumption that the Communist Party will always put the economy ahead of the environment.

item.title: Can social media become less hateful by law? Germany is trying it - and failing, critics say.
item.dc:creator: Rick Noack
item.description: "Social networks are no charity organizations that guarantee freedom of speech in their terms of service,” a government representative said.

item.title: What does North Korea want from the Olympics? An expert in the politics of sports explains.
item.dc:creator: Adam Taylor
item.description: "It has become blindingly apparent that national pride and national strength are in part reflected in sporting success ... North Korea has embraced that."

item.title: Glee in London over Trump’s scrapped visit — but also unease about U.S.-British ties
item.dc:creator: Karla Adam
item.description: The president’s claim that he canceled because of a “bad” embassy deal was widely seen as an excuse.

item.title: Russian military was behind ‘NotPetya’ cyberattack in Ukraine, CIA concludes
item.dc:creator: Ellen Nakashima
item.description: The hack targeted banks, energy firms, senior government officials and an airport as Ukraine wages war against separatists aligned with the Kremlin.

item.title: UPDATE 5-German Social Democratic leaders beg members to back deal with Merkel
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: The agreement pledges to strengthen the euro zone and crackdown on arms sales to countries in conflict zones.

item.title: Russian hackers who compromised DNC are targeting the Senate, company says
item.dc:creator: Shane Harris
item.description: The spear-phishing attempts involved websites meant to look like the email system available only to people using the Senate’s internal computer network.

item.title: The U.S. ambassador in London contradicted just about everything Trump said about the new embassy
item.dc:creator: Alex Horton
item.description: Ambassador to the U.K. Robert Johnson said the U.S. “had” to relocate the embassy due to security concerns.

item.title: After drubbing by media, Trump's ambassador to the Netherlands apologizes for anti-Muslim remarks
item.dc:creator: Eli Rosenberg
item.description: Pete Hoekstra said he was wrong to voice unsupported theories about Muslim “no-go zones” and politicians being “burned” in Europe in the past.

item.title: Publication of beloved novelist's anti-Semitic pamphlets suspended in France
item.dc:creator: James McAuley
item.description: Since it was announced, the project has shocked and scandalized a society where the written word remains a matter of fierce debate.

item.title: 'As usual, he's dead wrong': Former U.S. ambassadors explain London Embassy move after Trump criticism
item.dc:creator: Adam Taylor
item.description: How security concerns led the United States to move its London Embassy.

item.title: U.S. military history is rich with immigrants who left the countries Trump disparaged and sacrificed in combat
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: The U.S. military is a kaleidoscope of cultures, races and religions, with units pulling together to meet common goals under occasionally brutal circumstances.

item.title: Venezuela’s solution to a collapsing economy and rampant violence: Woo tourists
item.dc:creator: Anthony Faiola
item.description: The government hopes to follow in Cuba’s footsteps. Good luck, hoteliers say.

item.title: 'Here is what my #shithole looks like’: African countries and Haiti react to Trump's remark
item.dc:creator: Paul Schemm
item.description: Across Africa, the Caribbean and Central America, there was outrage over Trump’s dismissal of their nations.

item.title: Trump’s new ambassador ignored questions from Dutch reporters. Now, U.S. reporters want answers.
item.dc:creator: Eli Rosenberg
item.description: The State Department distanced itself from Peter Hoekstra's anti-Muslim remarks, saying “the ambassador made mistakes.”

item.title: Pakistan’s Imran Khan talks US relations as elections loom
item.dc:creator: Kathy Gannon | AP
item.description: Famed cricketer turned politician Imran Khan said Saturday that meeting U.S. President Donald Trump would be a “bitter pill” to swallow should he become Pakistan’s prime minister in elections later this year, but added “I would meet him.”

item.title: Guatemala arrests lawmaker in 2015 killing of 2 journalists
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: A ruling-party lawmaker accused of orchestrating the murder of two journalists in 2015 was arrested in southwestern Guatemala on Saturday.

item.title: France’s playful baby panda makes 1st public appearance
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: France’s first baby panda has made his grand public entrance by acting like many five-month-olds — climbing all over his mother, who looked like she just wanted to rest instead.

item.title: Correction: Turkey-US story
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: In a story on Jan. 12 about a travel advisory warning Turks traveling to the United States, The Associated Press quoted a Turkish Foreign Ministry regarding an incident at Ohio University. In November 2016, a student at Ohio State University, not Ohio University, intentionally drove a car into pedestrians on campus and attacked people with a knife. A corrected version of the story is below:

item.title: Czech president leads voting, but will face runoff election
item.dc:creator: Karel Janicek | AP
item.description: Czech President Milos Zeman failed to win re-election during the first round of a presidential election Saturday and will face a runoff in two weeks against the former head of the country’s Academy of Sciences.

item.title: Islamic State group offshoot claims 2017 Niger attack on US
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: An Islamic State group offshoot is claiming it carried out the October attack in Niger that killed four U.S. soldiers and four Nigerien troops and sparked questions about U.S. military involvement in West Africa’s vast Sahel region.
